newsitem.title: USA: Systems of Excellence chairman Huttoe sentenced.
newsitem.headline: Systems of Excellence chairman Huttoe sentenced.

text.p: A federal judge Friday sentenced Charles Huttoe, former chairman of Systems of Excellence Inc., to 46 months in prison for his role in a scheme to manipulate the price of the company's stock.
James Catheris, U.S. District Court judge for the Eastern District of Virigina, also fined Huttoe $10,000 and ordered that after prison his activities be monitored for two years.

The Securities and Exchange Commission had charged that Huttoe manipulated the market for the company's stock by issuing false, favourable information through a stock promoter and then selling his shares after the price had risen.
Huttoe pleaded guilty on Nov., 13, 1996, to one count of securities fraud and one count of money laundering.
The SEC charged that from March 1995 through September 1996 Huttoe distributed about 11 million shares of unregistered company stock to family members and others.
It also charged that Huttoe transferred about $7.6 million in trading profits from brokerage accounts that had been opened in the names of the relatives and others.
The SEC in November sued Systems of Excellence, a maker of video teleconferencing equipment with offices in Virginia and Florida, and Huttoe.
The agency is still seeking to recover more than $12 million in illegal profits from the sale of securities by Huttoe, a Miami resident, and members of his family, it said.
